Likely % achieved issue: Stantec set an emissions reduction goal of 40% reduction of our per employee Scope 1 and 2 emissions (with a baseline of 2013 and completion of 2028). We applied Science Based Target (SBT) criteria as best we could to our type of company, but, because SBT do not yet apply to professional service firms, we are not able to yet certify our targets. We considered the Sectoral Decarbonization Approach (SDA) methodology (2015) in setting our goals, which predicts a 55% carbon intensity reduction in 'service space' per square meter by 2050. We set a goal of 40% reduction by 2028 as the first step of meeting that goal. Because we are making quicker progress than anticipated in making our reduction goal, we are considering resetting our reduction goal again next year and will again look to apply SBT criteria.Please note, Stantec has a growth strategy of 15% per year based on a combination of organic and acquisition growth. As such, we are always adding staff, locations, and revenue. Our strategy is to make consistent changes with ourselves and those acquired companies to reduce our emissions. Because of that, we track our progress though the reduction of emissions generated by each employee. While our absolute emissions may grow due to company expansion, our per person impact is progressively smaller.

Likely % achieved issue: This target has been revised following a review of energy data during the group's 2018 Sustainability Assurance Audit for the 2018 Integrated Annual Report. The target is therefore reported as new, as the base year and its data sets were changed to correspond with the updated energy data. A key finding by the external auditor was inaccuracies in the reporting of energy data by operations. The operations have been dependent on consumption values from municipality and Eskom accounts, rather than using their own meter readings for reporting. In addition, the consumption values for one of the operations was inaccurate due to the municipality not including a 10 multiplier for the meter readings since 2015. On the basis of this, the group has agreed to relook at the emission reduction targets and have corrected all 2017 data to use this as the baseline year going forward.

Likely % achieved issue: Based on the concept of eco-efficiency, we have set goals to ensure that all people can lead affluent lifestyles in harmony with the Earth as envisaged in our long-term vision, \Environmental Vision 2050.\"Eco-efficiency can be expressed as a fraction, with the creation of new value as the numerator and environmental impacts as the denominator. The more enriched value created - or the more environmental impacts are reduced and progress made toward coexisting with the Earth - the more eco-efficiency improves. We call the degree of improvement in eco-efficiency the \"Factor,\" and increasing the Factor leads to affluent lifestyles in harmony with the Earth.Based on several predictions about the future shapes society may take, we examined how much we need to raise the Factor by 2050. It is assumed that the gross domestic product (GDP) of a country reflects value that its people can enjoy. According to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), the world's average GDP per capita is expected to grow 3.4 times by 2050. It is also expected that the world population will increase by 1.5 times compared to 2000 by 2050. And at the Conference of Parties to the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, participants emphasized that it is necessary to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by half by 2050. If the three points cited previously are taken into account, the required degree of improvement in eco-efficiency (Factor) in the world in 2050 is 10.2 (3.4 * 1.5 * 2). In light of this, Toshiba Group has made it a goal to achieve Factor 3 by 2020 and Factor 10 by 2050."

In 2018, we announced our new Sustainability Goals for 2025 related to greenhouse gas emissions, energy, water, waste, safety and diversity from a 2017 baseline. These goals continue our commitment to address our environmental and social impacts and address topics most material to Johnson Controls and our stakeholders. This strategy drives sustainability across our entire value chain by focusing on five areas: solutions, people, partnerships, performance and governance. As part of this new strategy, we are committing to new, ambitious 2025 performance targets related to greenhouse gas emissions, energy, water, waste, safety and diversity from a 2017 baseline:- 25% reduction for energy and greenhouse gas intensity- 10% reduction for water use at stressed locations - 25% of manufacturing locations landfill-free- 25% reduction in recordable safety incidents- Increase diverse supplier spend at a rate exceeding revenue growthJohnson Controls takes an enterprise approach to reducing our greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, which is linked closely to our activities on energy reduction. We are committed to continuously reducing the environmental impact of our own operations, which includes our manufacturing plants, distribution centers, service centers, offices, fleets and other operations worldwide. We look across the lifecycle of our business, including emissions upstream, within our global operations and downstream. Our emissions reduction strategies include improving energy efficiency, using renewable energy (either on-site or off-site), tracking and managing emissions using information technology, and exploring how demand response, energy storage, and other new technologies can continue to help us manage our emissions. Additionally, we continuously seek cost-competitive lower-carbon electricity and other energy, voluntarily purchasing RECs (renewable energy certificates) making sure they are additional to the green power that may already be offered in the standard electricity mix. We also have on-site renewable energy in some of our locations.

This factor, SCCOP, is used by our business units except NWK (aka SubCom, our ship based company) and parts of MED. Regarding the anticipated change in absolute GHG emissions corresponding to this intensity goal, TE Connectivity has a growth strategy which includes acquisitions as well as organic growth. As new business are acquired and new locations are added to the company the absolute GHG emissions from those new businesses and locations will partially off-set absolute decreases at other locations. Because it is unknown what acquisitions will be completed and what the increase in organic growth will be in any given year, we do not have a reliable way to predict the absolute change. This is the third time we have achieved a 10% normalized reduction over 3 years.

The presented normalized base year emission represents an average for all business units and is not used for monitoring purposes. In 2016, after COP21 and our commitment to Paris-Pledge, we decided to take action and determine a long term target emission intensity reduction target that covers our yearly-basis targets. Scope 3 emissions are not included within the scope of our intensity target. IPCC Fifth Assessment Report factors are used for global warming potentials and emission factors. Grid Emission Factor is calculated based on the most recent data available by TEIAS. GHG emissions are reported following the guidance in GRI 305-1 Direct greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (Scope 1), GRI 305-2 Energy indirect greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (Scope 2) and the GHG Protocol - Location-based. % of target achieved: No, but we anticipate setting one in the next 2 years
Likely % achieved issue: Last year the Bank implemented a new target that is based on Net Revenue, rather than FTE. The target requires a 30% reduction in Scope 1 + 2 emissions per net revenue in rupees crore (Rs Cr) over a period of 5 years. Starting from 2017-2018 (base year) and ending in 2022-2023. This target is outlined in our Environment Policy. The target for 2022-2023 is thus 30% of 5.19 = 3.63 MT of CO2e/ Net Rev in Cr. We have already achieved 40% of this target as our emissions per net revenue (in crores) has reduced from 5.19 last year to 4.57 in FY 2018-2019. Here 2018 refers to FY 2017-2018 and 2023 refers to FY 2022-2023. This is a NEW target. Since our target is an intensity target and the Bank is expanding its operations we expect our absolute emissions to increase for all scopes (1, 2 and 3). We can only calculate the anticipated change in absolute terms for scope 1 and 2 as an intensity target has only been identified for these scopes. Total Net Rev (2017-2018): 12,247.55 Crore Total Projected Net Rev based on an estimated 25% year-on-year increase (2022-2023): 37,376.55 Crore The emissions intensity target per Net Revenue (in Cr.) for 2022-2023 is 3.63 MT Co2e/Net Rev (Crores), and the expected Scope 1+2 emissions for 2017-2018 is 3.63 * 37,376.55 = 135,818.61The % anticipated change in emissions has thus been calculated as follows: (Expected emissions - Base Year Emissions) / Base Year Emissions *100 = ((135,818.61 - 63578.63)/63578.63)*100 = 114%Absolute Scope 1 and 2 emissions are thus expected to increase by 114% by the target year as a result of the exponential growth of the Bank's business and operations.

Likely % achieved issue: As a global player in transport and logistics, Bollore Logistics have an important role to play to fight against climate change, that is is the reason why the Bollore Group started to define emissions target for this specific division. Moreover, Bollore Logistics represents 32% of the greenhouse gas emissions (scope 1&2) of the Group. Regarding its climate strategy, and with a view to contributing to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, Bollore Logistics has drawn on the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBT) to bring its target in line with the 2C threshold. As a result, the Company is committed to reducing emission intensity by 30% CO2eq with regard to scopes 1 and 2 by 2027 compared to 2017. For Scope 3, Bollore Logistics commits with customers and suppliers to offer eco-innovative solutions towards a greener world. As a member of the Clean Cargo Working Group and EcoTransIT World, we aim, together with our partners and suppliers, at contributing to industry developments as required, in particular through any available tool and technology conducive to achieving a more responsible supply chain. With some of them, we have been working on long-term projects to bring about tangible and efficient reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and improvement of air quality.Analyzing environmental and social risks, anticipating change while integrating current and future customer's concerns are central to Bollore Logistics' strategy. The launch of the \Powering Sustainable Logistics\" Program demonstrates Bollore Logistics' will to place sustainable development and CSR centre stage of its operational model. Also, it expresses a far-reaching commitment and a genuine wish on our part to join in with those at the forefront of environmental and social value creation through our worldwide supply chain activities. The ''Powering Sustainable Logistics\" Program sets 54 targets to be achieved by 2025. They are translated in action plan deployed per department (real estate, procurement, QHSE, commercial offering ...) but also at local level in each region the company operating."

Likely % achieved issue: Petrofac has 3 business divisions - E&C, IES, and EPS.This emission intensity reduction target is established for Integrated Energy Services (IES) division.Emission intensity targets for business division IES is taken separately from the other two divisions due to nature of the business . IES division deploys traditional equity upstream investment models, including Production Sharing Contracts (PSC) and Production Enhancement Contracts (PECs) in upstream oil and gas industry. In year 2018 Petrofac has equity share in PM304- Malaysia, Chergui- Tunisia, Greater Stella- UK and Santuario -Mexico. IES contributes to 70-80% of the Petrofac Group absolute carbon emissions due to natural gas consumption for power generation, flaring and venting at the offshore and onshore assets. We aim to achieve a 2% year-on-year reduction in GHG intensity over baseline year of 2015, with a 20% reduction by 2030 in IES. The intensity metric is - Thousand metric ton CO2e per million BOE produced.Two other business divisions i.e. E&C and EPS includes project construction and duty holder services for the oil & gas and energy industry customers. These business divisions contribute to more than 90% of Petrofac revenues and between 20- 30% of the absolute emissions. Onshore and offshore EPC projects, duty holder service contracts for oil and gas assets, training offices and design engineering offices fall under these two business divisions. We aim to achieve a 2% year-on-year reduction in GHG intensity over the baseline year of 2015, with a 20% reduction by 2030 in these business divisions. % of target achieved: Yes, we consider this a science-based target, but this target has not been approved as science-based by the Science Based Targets initiative
Likely % achieved issue: Considering our commitment for setting science based targets, our Company presented to the SBTi team its proposed targets based in the methodology C-FACT, publicly disposed by Autodesk. According the scientific methodology in emerging countries a reduction of 50% in 2050 in absolute emissions must be achieved. Therefore our intensity target per revenue (millions of MXN) was adjusted and comprises a 50% reduction for 2025 (2.58 tonCO2/million pesos of revenue at mid-term) and 80% reduction for 2050 (1.03 tonCO2/million pesos of revenue at long term) against intensity of 2013. The base year 2013 was selected for its accuracy and certainty according its coverage (no exclusions) and its complete verification. Please bear in mind the emission figure provided for base year is the one published in the 2015 CDP report, which includes emission figures for 2013 with and adjustment on their electricity emission factor (the electricity emission factor is published by SEMARNAT -the Mexican Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources- with one year of lag). Figures used in the base year were 69,647.51 tonCO2e and $13,508 million pesos of revenues. The proposed targets (absolute and intensity for S1 and S2) are not validated yet by Science Based Targets Initiative because our lending and investment activities represent more than 5% of our annual revenues (the SBTi threshold for financial institutions' Scope 3 significance) and the methodology for setting SBT's for Scope 3 of financial sector has not been released yet. Thus, any targets of financial institutions cannot be officially reviewed by now.Due to our revenue growth of 33.67% and our emissions decreased 9.96% (both VS 2017) we already achieved our medium-term goal.

The calculation has been done by using GHG protocol tools station combustion, May 18, 2015, added GWP values from IPCC, s fifth assessment report. For purchased electricity, we are using May 18, 2015, added IEA emission factors for the year 2012 and the latest GWP values from IPCC fifth assessment report.We are already going for formal communication for adopting science-based target initiatives (SBTI). Primary analysis already is done, besides this we are taking challenges to reduce GHG to support Walmart project gigaton. Since Walmart first launched our sustainability goals in 2005, we have learned that incorporating sustainability in everyday work is good for business, good for people and good for the environment. It has made us a better company and showed us that when we work with others, we can make a greater impact.That's why in 2016, Walmart set a new goal to reduce emissions in our supply chain by 1 gigaton (1 billion metric tons) by 2030. To achieve this goal, Walmart is launching Project Gigaton - an opportunity for suppliers and organizations to join Walmart in reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the supply chain.For promoting project Gigaton, we are using RedE platform from 2018, which is providing us online monitoring engines for setting targets and implementing results, guidelines, etc. Apart from it, Epic group audited all the facilities by recognized third party and energy auditors. Each and every facility takes those all green initiatives which can reduce the GHG is given below:1. Installation of the Exhaust gas boiler2. Installation the garments trap in the iron section3. Installation of energy-efficient lights4. Insulation of steam pipes and valves5. Reduction of compressed air consumption by using air nozzles instead of open pipes6. Improvement of Condensate Recovery System7. Replacement of existing submersible pump by energy-efficient pump8. Repairing steam traps9. Maintaining the housekeeping of compressors room & distribution system10. Calibration of different gauges and meters used in the processing area11. Awareness-raising session on a regular basis about energy conservation

% of target achieved: Yes, we consider this a science-based target, but this target has not been approved as science-based by the Science Based Targets initiative
Likely % achieved issue: Befimmo still has a target of cutting the CO2e emissions related to controlled indirect energy consumption by 17%, and the CO2e emissions related to uncontrolled indirect energy consumption by 17% (excluding offsets) of its buildings. It is well aware that this ambitious aim of reducing its environmental impact can be influenced by the constantly changing needs and behaviours of society, the world of work, especially through the use of new technologies and/or a new form of mobility that is now more geared towards electricity, but it intends to stand firmly by this target.This approach assumes flexibility and anticipation of the electricity needs that Befimmo will immediately integrate into all of its projects. Befimmo also aims to limit its CO2e emissions, in particular by continuing to invest in renewable energy generation. Depending on the configuration of the buildings and any subsidies granted on account of their geographical situation, a study of the photovoltaic potential carried out in 2017 enabled Befimmo to identify a number of opportunities for projects to be emplemented quickly, together with the technical and financial resources required. All the sites identified as having a high potential are being installed or extended. This work on two buildings located in Brussels and representing an additional area of some 650 m of solar panels will be completed during the first quarter of 2019. The additional area will complement the 3,854 m of panels already installed. Furthermore, by the end of 2019, self-generation by all these installations should cover electricity needs equivalent to the annual consumption of some 150 households. The feasibility study will be updated In 2019. We will systematically consider installing solar panels on buildings to be built and/or renovated.

% of target achieved: Yes, we consider this a science-based target, but this target has not been approved as science-based by the Science Based Targets initiative
Likely % achieved issue: Our target has a long-term objective of continuous improvement. In this respect, we look at least to 2020 to maintain our objective of not increase our emissions. This is aligned with the 2 degrees objectives since on one hand the company has achieved and is expected to continue to achieve double-digit growth, whereas our emissions ambition is to cap at 2009 levels. On top of this, Amadeus invests 18% of its revenues in R&D and this helps airlines and other customers to meet their own scope 1 and 2 targets.We aim at stabilizing our absolute emissions. Given the company's continuous growth, in practical terms, this target requires that we improve our intensity performance. Since we don't know the growth of the company in advance, our target is to at least maintain the same performance as last year. In order to measure our emissions performance, we have developed a system that factors in company growth to assign varying weights to absolute and intensity targets according to company growth. This process assigns more weight to absolute targets when the company grows slowly or remains stable, and the system assigns more weight to intensity targets when the company grows fast.Before 2018, we reported the emissions of our top sites included in our Environmental Management System (EMS). This represented the emissions of approximately 70% of our workforce and of our Data Center. From 2018 onwards, we have reported both the emissions obtained thought direct reporting (70% of workforce + Data Center) and have also included the estimation of the emissions from the remaining 30% of workforce that was not included in our reporting before 2018). This new methodology has been validated by our external verification company KPMG.Analyzing in more detail our performance, we have reduced scope 1+2 emissions per employee by 59.85% (1.807 tons CO2 per employee) in the reporting year compared to the year before (2017). This is particularly remarkable considering that we have expanded our coverage and if we consider the base year, we also reduced this ratio by 72.66%, so it shows a very positive trend. This calculation includes the deduction of 16,410 tons of CO2 of our scope 2 emissions that have been offset by Amadeus using UNFCCC CERs. Without taking into account offset, our emissions per employee have also been significantly reduced.

sectors: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
% of target achieved: No, but we are reporting another target that is science-based
Likely % achieved issue: Our headline target is to reduce aircraft CO2 emissions by 30% per Revenue Tonne Kilometre (RTK) from 2007 to 2021. RTK is a standard aviation efficiency metric and is defined as the utilised (sold) capacity for passengers and cargo expressed in metric tonnes, multiplied by the distance flown. For transparency, each year we also report in full our CO2e from aircraft fuel use and our CO2 per passenger km in our sustainability report. This target covers 99.9% of scope 1 emissions. 10 years into our target period, we've reduced the CO2 per RTK by 18.1% from 0.869 kgCO2/RTK to 0.712 kgCO2/RTK. RTK calculates passengers and freight flown, multiplied by the Great Circle Distances (GCD), airport to airport distance. The GCD is multiplied by 8% to allow for 'real world' distances flown, e.g. sub-optimal routing and stacking at airports during periods of heavy congestion. Though there is still some way to go to meet our target, we have not yet completed our fleet renewal. We added three 787 in 2018, and 12 A350s will be switched into our fleet by the end of 2021; each aircraft will be on average 30% more fuel efficient than the aircraft it replaces. This along with more efficient flight procedures and increasing load factors should help us get close to reaching our target in 2021. Variables such as aircraft orders, load factors and growth make estimation prone to uncertainty. This is our best estimate based on modelling provided by our airline planning team.

Likely % achieved issue: At Virgin Atlantic, we support the International Air Transport Association (IATA) climate targets for aviation introduced in 2009 (aviation industry agreed targets): 1 - An average improvement in fuel efficiency of 1.5% per year from 2009 to 2020 2 - A cap on net aviation CO2 emissions from 2020 (carbon-neutral growth) 3 - A reduction in net aviation CO2 emissions of 50% by 2050, relative to 2005 levels The first of these targets is captured here as our second intensity target Int2. This is an annual target, where we look to improve our efficiency each year by at least 1.5% relative to the previous year. Unfortunately, in 2018 our efficiency measure was very similar to the 2017 value (0.711 kg vs 0.712kg). This is a very slight decrease in our efficiency. Like other airlines, we experienced supply issues with the Rolls Royce Trent 1000 engine on our 787-9 aircraft. This meant we had to make changes to our flying programme to support additional engine maintenance activity. On average this resulted in two of our most fuel efficient planes being parked each month. At the same time, to ensure continuity of service for our customers, we delayed retirement of older, less efficient aircraft and introduced four additional A330-200s into our fleet. This resulted in our static efficiency results in 2018. However is it worth noting that if we calculate our overall emission intensity reductions since 2009 we are ahead of where the IATA target would require us to be in 2020. And we expect to see further improvements in our carbon performance as the 787-9 issues are resolved, and our 12 new A350s come into service from 2019

Each year we have continued this investment, whether it's procuring a data center in Wenatchee, Washington that is 100% clean-powered by the local utility to achieving LEED certification for various sites around the world. In 2018, we're proud to report that our absolute emissions decreased while our revenue increased by 36% from the base year. In 2018, we achieved an intensity metric of 1.7 MT CO2e per revenue in millions. This is a 63% decrease from our base year, surpassing our 10% reduction goal. In 2015, this intensity metric was 4.58 MT CO2e. To continue meeting this intensity target over the next year, VMware will continue to aggressively pursue energy efficiency in our facilities, operations and data center. Note: the intensity figure above (4.58) is calculated with our revenue in millions. We have continued this format for consistency since this is how this metric has been reported in previous years.

As Arqos' scope 1 target is specific to cement production, and only CO2 emissions from cement production were measured in the baseline year (2006), the percentage of emissions considered in the scope 1 is 100%.As a result of the company's efforts to reduce direct GHG emissions, Argos achieved 616 kgCO2/t cementitious product in 2018, a reduction of 16% in comparison to the 2006 baseline of 735 kgCO2/t cementitious product. This 16% reduction that was obtained in 2018 with respect to the base year 2006 means that 65% of the goal to 2025 (which is 25%) has already been completed. In other words: % of target achieved = (16/25)*100 = 65%The projected decrease in absolute scope 1 emissions reported takes into account the forecast of production in each strategic region by 2025 and the expected CO2 intensity in each one. The indirect CO2 emissions (scope 2 and scope 3) are calculated and monitored by Argos; however, the Company has no public targets for reduction of these emissions yet. Argos has a location-based scope 2 emissions target but for internal communications purposes; as it is still in the process of being developed fully and is under changes and adjustments, the company has decided not to disclose it yet.

Likely % achieved issue: The 25% revenue intensity reduction (Int 1) is our first target and was set in early 2014. As of 12/31/18, we had achieved a 21.2% reduction in revenue-based emissions intensity. We had achieved 84.6% (21.2% / 25%) of progress toward the Int 1 target in 75% (6 / 8 years) of time to target. We expect to achieve the Int 1 target by or before 2020 target year.If we were to continue absolute emission reduction at the rate of the past three years (2016-2018), we will achieve 14.9% absolute emission reduction by 2020. We expect that rate to be maintained or accelerated for the Int 1 target boundary.As of 12/31/18, an absolute emissions reduction of 6.2% and 1949 mT CO2e had been achieved, compared to base year 2012. 6.2% = ((31,515 - 29,566)) / 31,515).This target includes at least 99% of the company's total, global gross Scope 1+2 emissions for base year 2012.What is not covered by this target are small facilities and facilities scheduled for demolition. We reassess our operational control boundary annually and did so in Q1 2019. We have a number of small facilities along with several unoccupied facilities scheduled for demolition. All emissions from these facilities are less than 1% of total emissions covered by the target reporting boundary. When conducting the annual boundary assessment, if we identify relevant emissions not previously reported we restate prior year emissions to include them.IPC Group (acquired in April 2017) emissions are reported as part of 2018 total Scope 1+2 emissions. IPC Group represents 20% of our 2018 market-based Scope 1+2 emissions, but IPC is not part of 2016 base year emissions for the Int 1 target.We intend to make 2019 or 2020 the base year for new SBTs which will include IPC, as well as Gaomei - acquired in early 2019.

Likely % achieved issue: ---Relevance: Sodium carbonate is an energy-intensive production and electricity and steam are used process. In our combined heat and power plant, carbon emission-intensive fossil fuel lignite is used. At this combined heat and power - CHP, the efficiency of steam production and electricity production have a significant impact on the carbon intensity per kWh electricity and per kWh steam. On the other side, we cannot produce 100% of the electricity consumed in the processes by the CHP. 80-85% of electricity is supplied from the grid.---Methodology: In 2012 we set a base year intensity goal target by 60% until 2040 as a long-term target. For this target, The GHG Protocol Mitigation Goal Standard has been used as a guide to design a standardized approach for assessing and reporting progress toward goal achievement. All the requirements have been fulfilled stated in The GHG Protocol Mitigation Goal Standard; GHG inventory, calculation, recalculation of the baseline. Our Normalized base year emissions covered by target (metric tons CO2e) 2012 calculated as 0.609098668 Metric tons CO2e per metric ton of product---% of target achieved: An emission reduction of 35.86% has been achieved in 2018. Normalized base year emissions covered by target (metric tons CO2e) in 2018 calculated as 0.390673729 Metric tons CO2e per metric ton of product. --Why we believe this target to be a science-based target: According to IPCC Fifth Assessment Report RCP2.6 scenario, in order to stay under 2C to by 2050 from 2010 levels, it is required that at least a 49% reduction. Internally, we also use a climate scenario of A2 of IPCC outlining the climate change risks. Therefore, we envaulted our target being a science-based target because this target is 60% reduction (more than 49%) from the 2012 baseline.

Likely % achieved issue: The result of DB's Group intensity Target is reported annually in our Integrated Report. We measure the carbon efficiency of our core business activities by calculating a \carbon efficiency index\" from the different emission intensities and efficiencies in our transport divisions, such as a) metric tons CO2e per passenger kilometer (passenger transport rail), b) metric tons CO2e per metric ton kilometer (freight transport), c) metric tons CO2e per vehicle kilometer produced (passenger transport bus, rail outside Germany) and stationary sites/activities, such as metric tons CO2e per track-km/ton-km/train-km/stations operated/m3 GBV. The index value is set to 100 for the base year 2006, for steering purposes we apply the respective annual value minus 100 (equals to a value \"-x%\"). For the calculation of emissions coming from traction current in Germany (DB's RU) we apply a market-based approach whereas the national railway businesses outside Germany are calculated with the respective national electricity mix with source EcoTransIT World. Emissions resulting from sites we apply emissions factors for each energy carrier (e.g. natural gas, electricity, heating oil) from the GEMIS database, provided by the scientific institution IINAS."

Likely % achieved issue: Our GHG intensity reduction target is one of four voluntary, operational sustainability targets set for 2025. The greenhouse-gas emissions intensity, measured in metric tons of CO2e per metric ton of product sales, fell from 1.23 in 2017 to 1.22 in 2018. This marks a 10.2 percent reduction from our 2010 baseline. Please note that there is no methodology for chemical sector within Science Based Target framework. We estimate that our 25% reduction target by 2025 represents 1.7% annual reduction trajectory. We estimate that this is in line with overall long term reduction trajectory required for the global chemical industry under 2C scenario called Clean Technology Scenario, developed by the International Energy Agency in the \Future of Petrochemicals\" study (ref: https://www.iea.org/petrochemicals/). We currently actively pursue development of chemical sector methodology for SBT framework. Once the method is developed we commit to technical feasibility analysis against our current target. Among the projects that helped us to reduce emissions in 2018, is the one carried out by our Ibn Zahr affiliate to clean heater coils at its MTBE-2 plant, reducing the site's emissions by 4,300 metric tons of CO2e each year. Our Petrokemya PVC team conducted a successful upgrade to eliminate undesirable cleaning processes, increasing productivity while reducing emissions by 1,440 tons of CO2 per year. We continue to benefit from our carbon capture and utilization plant at United - the world's largest carbon utilization facility. The plant's load will increase to maximum capacity once a new ethylene glycol plant at United is operational in 2021. Please refer to SABIC Sustainability Report 2018 (page 40) for more information."

Starting from the reporting year, 2018, Tier 3 approach is applied as per the regulation. We calculated our 2018 emissions as per Tier 3 which is company specific factors based on the analysis. In Mersin and Kayseri plants, upon the demand of the customer, high-resistance products were produced and this led to an increase in our emissions from fuel. As a result, our emissions per ton of clinker has increased to 878 from 872 compared to the base year.

Likely % achieved issue: Normalization is Metric Tonnes CO2e per USD $1000 Gross Sales. The reduction goal represents the intent of current and future energy consumption reduction initiatives and currently does not consider available offsets or RECs. The initial goal is to reduce overall consumption without offsetting through RECs, although the use of RECs and offsets may be employed at a future date. The emissions scope includes all company electric and natural gas usage; employed for facility operations and process energy in our manufacturing facilities and administrative buildings. The emissions scope additionally includes all emissions from our company owned transportation/delivery fleet and our operations/admin ground fleet. Excluded from the scope are fugitive emissions and emissions from our privately owned wood burning boilers. Boiler emissions are excluded from scope 1 emissions because they utilize bio-based wood waste as fuel.During 2016 we met our intensity target of 25% emissions reduction. We used a baseline of 2009 and had a goal of reaching this by 2019. This required us to set a new goal this year and we have decided to use the 2016 emissions numbers as our new baseline. In 2016 our MTCO2e per $1000 in Sales was 0.1685 and in 2017 it was 0.1436. We had a large increase in sales while reducing our absolute emissions. This resulted in a large single year drop in normalized emissions of 14.8%. We do not expect this large of a decrease every year as generally our emissions will increase as sales, and resulting energy usage, increases. However, with current sale projections and continued efficiency improvments we do expect to continue to see decreases in our normalized emissions.For the question below: The larger percentage increase in absolute emissions can be expected if sales goals are met or exceeded in between our initial reporting year (2016) and target year (2030). This is comparing the target year to only the base year of 2016. Estimations of growth calculated by using sales growth between 2016 and 2017 period. % of absolute emissions increase was calculated assuming sales goals were met and OFS still met its emissions intensity target of 50% reduction by 2030.

Likely % achieved issue: In line with the fuel mix revamp proposed in the Government's consultation document in 2014, the carbon intensity will be reduced by 50-60% by 2020 as compared with 2005. We are committed to low carbon development. Our strategies align closely with the Government's policy to meet the challenging goal of reducing the carbon intensity. The Government proposed in its Consultation Document in 2015 that fuel mix with 50% gas, 25% nuclear and 25% coal and RE. We have started to construct a new gas fired unit, L10, at Lamma Power Station (LPS) in 2016. With higher efficiency, L10 will emit ~ 25% less CO2 than an existing older gas-fired unit at LPS, for the same amount of electricity generated. In September 2016, the Government gave us the green light for the construction of another gas-fired generating unit, L11. This unit will replace an ageing, less efficient gas-fired unit scheduled to retire in 2022. Both L10 and L11 will feature advanced technology that will reduce carbon emissions by about 25% as compared with the gas-fired unit due to retire. After the commissioning of L10 and L11 in 2020 and 2022 respectively, the electricity we produce through gas-fired generation will increase to about 50% and 55%, contributing to achieving the Government' carbon intensity reduction target for the city.

Likely % achieved issue: This medium term target for Cellnex Spain aims at reducing 30% of our scope 2 emissions relative to the authorized kW by 2020 compared to 2015, which are associated with our electricity consumption. The target aims at reducing the Group's electricity consumption through the implementation of several energy efficiency measures, such as: the acquisition of higher efficient UPS (Uninterruptible power supply); the substitution of separator transformers by electrical protections; the management of the Energy consumption related to cooling machines (tracking information about weather conditions affecting the sites) in order to be alerted in the event of over-consumption or over-cooling; and the development of a free cooling system that exploits natural refrigeration and maximises the advantages provided by climatic conditions (to reduce the energy consumption of air conditioning), among other initiatives. Despite having implemented several energy efficiency and electricity reduction initiatives, Cellnex Spain's scope 2 emissions relative to the authorized kW increased by 8% from 2015 to 2018. And thus, we indicate as 0% the 5 of emissions achieved.This increase is mainly due to the increase in the emission factor of the main electricity distribution companies (increases of emission factors of up to 133% compared to last year). In addition, this increase in the KPI is also due to the increase in our installed power in our sites in Spain (by 12,92% in 2018 compared to 2017 and by 31,55% in 2018 compared to 2015). However, and as a result of the implementation of several energy efficiency initiatives, Cellnex Spain has increased its energy efficiency by KW installed: the electricity consumption (kwh) per power installed (kw) has decreased by 3,52% in 2018 compared to last year and by 8,39% compared to 2015.

Indeed we consider we are as much responsible for scope 3 as for scopes 1 and 2. Company growth forecast is around +174% of quantities sold from 2016 to 2026 and our intensity target is to reduce kgCO2/quantity sold by 40% in 2026. Without intensity reduction we would increase by +174% scopes 1, 2, 3 emissions following the business activity trend. We followed the Science Based target methodology to define this target. Scope 1: Absolute Contraction based on IPCC AR5 (RCP2.6), linear annual reductions equivalent to c.1.7% YoY reductionScope 2: SDA Intensity convergence - Power Generation (IPCC AR5 RCP2.6)Scope 3: -Road transportation: SDA Intensity convergence - Transport (IPCC AR5 RCP2.6) -For other activities without methodology we defined a target based on strategic actions we have validated: PURCHASED GOODS,SERVICES, USE & END OF LIFE-100% of our industrial Partners consume Electricity from Renewable sources in 2026.- Reduction of 20% energy intensity consumption for these industrial partners and key suppliers. - To go towards 100% of new product design to be eco designed from 2021- Increase use life of product (circular economy business) with 10% of products to be reused by different users. BUSINESS TRAVELS, EMPLOYEE COMMUTING & CUSTOMERS TRAVELS We set a target of 20% kgCO2/product

% of target achieved: No, but we anticipate setting one in the next 2 years
Likely % achieved issue: The intensity target (average of 500 gCO2 per kWh of generated electricity between 2018 and 2020) applies to direct CO2 emissions from Uniper stationary assets selected under the financial control consolidation approach. Not included (less than 1%) are direct emissions (CO2 equivalents) from CH4 and N2O from fossil fuel combustion as well as direct emissions from mobile sources and combustion for internal purposes such as heating, pumping, etc. This is the first CO2 target disclosed by Uniper and is calculated yearly (calendar year) on the basis of well defined processes. The generation component includes electricity from all Uniper assets except 100% heat plants. Heat component from CHPs is converted into electricity equivalents. We consider 100% of target achievement as the intensity in 2018 was below the target (499g/kWh). Nonetheless, by definition the target is a three years average, therefore the intensity figure of 2018 cannot be understood as a target achievement. In regard to science based targets, Uniper needs to clarify if the reductions achieved since 1990 or 2005 through plant decommissioning are recognized for SBT or if only future reduction measures count from the SBT perspective. Depending on this we could commit to SBT.

Likely % achieved issue: Energy Conservation is a continuous and enduring process and it has been at the forefront of our strategies in curbing emissions. LTI is committed to enhancing the well-being of its Environment and our activities and achievements illustrate our efforts in this regard. Though, Business at LTI requires us to operate out of Office Spaces, we have taken up various Energy Conservation initiatives across all our offices in a phase-wise manner with least disturbances in day-to-day operations. We have taken up the following activities during the year in different phases:a. Replacing conventional Equipment with New Energy Efficient Equipment. b. HVAC Plant Optimisation,c. UPS Replacements and optimisation,d. Installation of LED Lights, Lighting Transformers, Motion Sensorse. Supplement electricity consumption with renewable or clean energy sources through Power Purchase Agreements.These initiatives have helped us achieve a reduction in electricity consumption to the tune of 8.5%. We have also achieved many milestones, from LEED Gold status for our headquarters in Powai by the US Green Building Council, Washington DC to taking up various initiatives on e-waste, energy consumption, water usage and waste disposal methods. These interventions were backed by persistent and proactive participation of LTIites. In FY 17-18, LTI has invested INR 21.4 million in energy conservation related projects which resulted in reducing 3,807 tonnes of carbon dioxide and an annual recurring energy saving of 2,126 Mwh. The same is assured by an independent assurance provider as part of Sustainability Report 2017-18.https://www.lntinfotech.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/LTI-Sustainability-Report-FY-2017-18.pdfThe key to the success of any 'green' initiative is not the enthusiasm with which it is initiated, but the rigour and discipline with which it is continuously implemented. Over three years ago, LTI launched a 'Go Green' initiative to sensitize employees to the importance of maintaining the ecological balance. We are in process of certification as per Indian Green Building Council for our Bangalore STPI office. - a prime example of our sustainability philosophy.The emission reduction target arrived is under the top management consideration. The same will be formally communicated once approved.

% of target achieved: Yes, this target has been approved as science-based by the Science Based Targets initiative
Likely % achieved issue: This target is approved by the SBTi and covers all Scope 1+2 and 86% of our Scope 3 emissions. This is in line with the scope requirements of the SBTi which require the target to include at least 2/3 of the scope 3 emissions. The scope 3 emissions covered under the target include all (subcontracted) transport up to the end-customer across the supply chain (scope 3, category 4) and the WTT emissions from fuels used in own trucks (scope 3 category 3). With this target scope we focus our reduction efforts on the large majority of our scope 3 emission on which we also have most influence and, therefore, can create the most impact. The remaining scope 3 categories are excluded from the science-based due to limited impact, lower quality of the underlying data and/or lower influence. These include: emissions from purchased goods and services, capital goods, waste generated in operations, employee commuting, business travel, upstream leased assets and rest fuel and energy related activities (from electricity and fuels used in buildings). Combined these excluded emissions cover only 14% of our total scope 3.These individual targets were aggregated to an overall intensity target. The intensity target metric we chose is kg of CO2 per metric ton of goods delivered as this metric best illustrates our actual performance across our supply chain. Please note that the metric we use is kg of CO2 instead of ton of CO2 as requested in this table.
T_ID: NA

% of target achieved: Yes, this target has been approved as science-based by the Science Based Targets initiative
Likely % achieved issue: This target is approved by the SBTi and covers all Scope 1+2 and 81% of our Scope 3 emissions. This is in line with the scope requirements of the SBTi which require the target to include at least 2/3 of the scope 3 emissions. We present our combined scope 1/2/3 target in this table which was determined by applying different science-based target methodologies for each individual activity in our Scope 1 + 2 (operated trucks and warehouses) and Scope 3 footprint (subcontracted transport). With this target scope we focus our reduction efforts on the scopes 1 and 2 and the large majority of our scope 3 emission on which we also have most influence and, therefore, can create the most impact. The remaining scope 3 categories not included in the target are excluded from the science-based target due to limited impact, lower quality of the underlying data and/or lower influence. These excluded scope 3 emissions include: ; emissions from purchased goods and services, capital goods, waste generated in operations, employee commuting, business travel, upstream leased assets and the scope 3 of rest of the fuel and energy related activities (from electricity and fuels used in buildings). Combined these excluded emissions cover only 19% of our total scope 3. These individual targets were aggregated to an overall intensity target. As intensity target metric we chose for kg of CO2 per metric ton of goods delivered as this metric best illustrates our actual performance across our supply chain. Please note that the metric we use is kg of CO2 instead of ton of CO2 as requested in this table.
